content:
Thunderbird doesn't look for profiles in the default location where profile folders are stored. Instead, it uses a profiles.ini file to keep track of the profiles it knows exist and where the corresponding profile folders are located. You're getting this error because Thunderbird cannot find the profile folder that profiles.ini is telling it to use. This could be because something bad happened to either the profile folder or to profiles.ini. I don't see how this could be related to what you said you did, but you may look at the contents of profiles.ini with a text editor in case there is something there that could shed some light on what happened.

Since you only seem to have a single profile, you may be able to fix the problem as follows:

  1. Quit Thunderbird if it's running.
  2. Take note of how the profile folder you have is named, because a new one will be created alongside it, and you'll need to differentiate between the two.
  3. Either delete profiles.ini, or rename it to something else, e.g. profiles.bak, if you want to keep it so you may try to figure what happened.
  4. Launch Thunderbird. Instead of looking for a profile folder that doesn't exist, it will create a new profiles.ini file with a new default profile and will let you proceed.
  5. You will be asked to set up a mail account, but you don't have to. You may cancel the account setup process and choose the option to Use Thunderbird without an email account when asked for confirmation.
  6. Choose Help > Troubleshooting Information from the menu bar.
  7. Click about:profiles in that page to open the About Profiles built-in Profile Manager.
  8. Create a New Profile, read the introductory text if this is new to you, then click Continue.
  9. Click Choose Folder and choose the profile folder you had there at the beginning.
  10. Name the profile however you want and click Done. You have now associated the profile folder with an actual profile that Thunderbird knows about.
  11. The new profile may have already been set as default. If not, use the Set as default button under it to make it so.
  12. Click Launch Profile under the new profile to start using it.
creator: DavidGG

content:
Richard403 said
I am currently using Thunderbird 115.3.1 (64-bit). The about info shows that I can update to 115.10.1, however, I believe there are much later versions but I don't know if I can update to the latest. My MacOS is 10.15.7 and that is the latest I can install. I have a large amount of email stored on my MAC and not in the cloud. I want to be able to access these emails that are on my hard drive, in addition to Thunderbird, in Apple Mail. I have researched and it appears that the best way is to export from Thunderbird is into the mbox format. However, there does not seem to be a way to do this in the version of Thunderbird I am using. How do I move all of my local email in Thunderbird to my Apple Mail? Thanks for any help, Richard

Thunderbird and apple mail do not share an MBOX format and have not since mac mail V1. So you might want to reconsider your plan.

Just to be clear, MBOX is the native storage format Thunderbird uses. However for those that are challenged by the file system and copying files, there is an addon. https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/?src=ss

content:
Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

content:
Mali ste si nainštalovať českú verziu Thunderbirdu a nie anglickú a tú potom veľmi ťažko počešťovať.

Stiahnite si najnovšiu oficiálnu SK, alebo CS verziu Thunderbirdu (dnes je to 135.0.1) pre Windows x32 alebo x64 z http://archive.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/ a uložte si tento inštalačný súbor do počítača. Po dokončení sťahovania zatvorte všetky okná Thunderbirdu. Odstráňte inštalačný priečinok Thunderbird, ktorý sa nachádza na jednom z týchto umiestnení Windows. Ak sú na obidvoch miestach, odstráňte obidva: C:\Program Files\Mozilla Thunderbird\ C:\Program Files (x86)\Mozilla Thunderbird\ Reštartujte počítač.

Teraz nainštalujte najnovšiu českú verziu Thunderbirdu pre Windows x32, alebo Windows x64. Dvakrát kliknite na stiahnutý inštalačný súbor a prejdite krokmi sprievodcu inštaláciou. Po dokončení sprievodcu kliknutím na tlačidlo Dokončiť otvorte Thunderbird.

content:
Antonio C G Bareggi said
reindexing hangs up ... and that's it

What do you mean by "reindexing"? Did you quit Thunderbird, delete the file global-messages-db.sqlite in the profile folder and restart Thunderbird? Creating the new global-messages-db.sqlite may take hours if you have many messages in many folders in many accounts. Maybe that's why you think it "hangs up". You can follow the indexing processus by opening the Activity Manager window via the Tools menu. Does TB really get unresponsive (hang up) or do you get an error message?

content: Thunderbird stores mail using text files in mbox format with no filename extension. Accompanying .msf files are index files that can be removed, they're automatically re-created when not present. You may copy the desired mbox files from their location in the old profile folder into Local Folders in the new profile folder. Thunderbird will recognise them and show them under Local Folders in the folder pane the next time it's launched.
creator: DavidGG

Hello again, thanks for all the info & help

So as previously stated, I now have my profile on my NAS and Thunderbird seems to be working OK.

I created a folder "Archive" under Local Folders and set this as the archive location in Account Settings, Copies & Folders. This created a folder Archive.sbd under Local Folders on the NAS. I then archived some old mail. In TB this created a series of year folders under the Archive folder. In these are files, some with .msf extensions, some with no extension but with the same filename.

This all looks familiar as it is the same folder & file structure as my old archive files. Do you have any further wisdom to impart?

Thanks again for your assistance.

Regards, Kevin
creator: truenorth1

content: You need an mbox file without filename extension or a .msf index file to make the corresponding folder appear in the folder pane in Thunderbird. An .sbd folder alone in the filesystem isn't enough by itself to cause the corresponding folder to appear in the folder pane in Thunderbird, and without that, Thunderbird won't show any other folders nested within the .sbd folder either.

content:
If you want the messages to be deleted when quitting Thunderbird, the setting is Account Settings > Server Settings > Empty Trash on Exit.

But if you want the messages to be removed from Bin/Trash after a given amount of time, then this setting is somewhat hidden, because in Thunderbird this is a folder setting, not an account setting. There is a corresponding account setting in Synchronization & Storage, but that applies to all the folders in the account, not just to Bin/Trash.

So right-click on the Bin/Trash folder, choose Properties, select the Retention Policy tab, uncheck 'Use my account settings', and choose your desired deletion settings there.
creator: DavidGG

content: I have been searching for a solution for a year time and again. And I just accidentally found the solution. So if you find yourself in the same situation: check that the response header "Content-Type: application/xml" is properly set on the response. That was my fault. Hope it helps someone.
creator: email227
